rounds.response:
I'm 940 chips deep, staring down an opponent who just 3-bet from the SB to 200. My range advantage as the 4-bettor pre-flop has collapsed, and I'm looking at Q♦ T♠—a solid but not premium hand.

Here are the crossfire facts:
- Pot sits at 260.
- Facing 140 to call.
- Pot odds ≈ 1.86 : 1 → need about 35 % equity to profitably continue.
- Villain’s line suggests a very strong range (QQ+, AK, maybe JJ/TT). My QTs is actually the bottom quarter of the 3-bet flat range. Plugging in worst-case (QQ+, AKs, AKo) I have ~23 % equity versus that range, vs ~27 % against the slightly wider JJ+, AKs. Even in an optimistic read I’m a significant underdog.

The stack-to-pot ratio is already ~3.8; if I flat here I’ll have ~740 behind. Any flop continuation bet forces me to commit a chunk of chips, likely OOP, with poor reverse implied odds as my Q-high flops outkicked vs AK/AQ on king/queen boards.

Therefore I retreat now and avoid bleeding another 700+ when dominated.

[Fold]

rounds.response:
I check back here. The flop 6♦ Q♠ A♦ misses me entirely; I have no pair, no flush draw, and only a gut-shot to Broadway. My opponent’s check in position means either (a) they also whiffed or (b) they’re keeping the pot small with a marginal ace / queen. Betting accomplishes very little: it only folds out air and lets better hands (any ace, queen, or diamond draw) continue. By checking I keep the pot cheap and realize the small equity I might still have.  

[Check]
